messages: 0da07476c4bd14079ce4032a6f280e17 (21:20): f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220: on documents that large, the only thing that works is either VI or emacs

0da07476c4bd14079ce4032a6f280e17 (21:28): OpenKomodo also handles some of the stuff I do ok-ish
0da07476c4bd14079ce4032a6f280e17 (21:28): (but it pretty much chokes on the html5 spec
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (21:42): f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220: you are on Mac, TextWrangler works
f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220 (21:47): I do my editing on the PC cause it has a bigger screen and better keyboard
f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220 (21:47): I just use this macbook for IRC, IM clients, email, browsing, etc.
f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220 (21:48): I also need to find a nice CVS and SVN client for the mac that gives me a simple GUI like TortoiseSVN/CVS do on Windows
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (21:50): uses command line and Eclipse
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (21:50): command line and emacs baby
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (21:50): (there's no other real solution that works under ssh)
f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220 (21:51): I like to avoid command line where possible, since it's requires too much typing
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (21:51): I just rediscovered that HTML5 floats and WF2 floats are different
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (21:51): that's what scripts are for
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (21:53): hmm. when I'm done with HTML5 (including WF2) datatypes, the only XSD thing left is ID or NCName
f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220 (21:53): hmm. OSX doesn't include the cvs command by default
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (21:53): f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220: it does if you install everything that came in the box
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (21:53): f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220: Leopard includes svn, too
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (21:53): yeah you might have to install the dev tools
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (21:53): (everything includes the Developer Tools)
f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220 (21:54): I installed the XCode tools earlier today
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (21:54): I need to come up with nice names for WF2 floats
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (21:55): nice names for code and nice names for UI
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (21:55): floating point number with optional exponent?
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (21:55): yeah, sorry about the mess there
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (21:55): not sure exactly what we should do with those
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (21:56): hopefully the forms task force will finish soon and we'll be able to finally merge WF2 with HTML5
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (21:56): (hahaha)
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (21:57): oh hey, only two more days til the "forms tf internal charter review period" ends
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (21:58): oops email, mimetype-list and charset-list have fallen through the cracks
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (21:58): more entries for the wiki page
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (21:58): more code to write
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (21:58): anyone want to lay odds on the review period being extended because everyone forgot to review the charter?
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (21:58): i give it about even odds
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (21:59): 69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e: saying it here is tampering with the odds
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (21:59): i guess so
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (21:59): though i don't know in which direction :-)
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (22:00): I feel tempted to restrict charset-list to charsets that are implemented and sane
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (22:00): but I guess in theory I should scrape the IANA registry
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (22:01): I expect unexpected craziness in the email datatype
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (22:01): i think i scoped out the craziness of the e-mail datatype
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (22:02): by picking a strategic entry point for you
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (22:02): ah. excellent. thanks
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (22:03): oh. cute. dependency on IDN and, therefore, Punycode
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (22:04): ah yeah, can't help you avoid that, sorry.
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (22:06): minor nit: I think you should say "addr-spec production" instead of "addr-spec token"
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (22:09): yeah, good point. can you send mail? i'll totally forget it by the time i get back to wf2.
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (22:09): 69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e: email sent
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (22:09): ta
f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220 (22:11): I haven't seen any comments on public-forms-tf about the charter since the telcon at the end of october. I don't think anyone has reviewed it :-)
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (22:12): f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220: yeah, exactly
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (22:12): it's not really clear to me that anyone on the task force actually really cares, to be honest
f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220 (22:13): nice to know the task force working as expected :-)
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (22:13): no comment
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (22:16): 69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e: is it intentional that 1. is a valid HTML5 float
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (22:16): it isn't a valid WF2 float
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (22:17): hmm. .1 is also not a valid WF2 float
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (22:20): i doubt any of the differences are intentional
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (22:20): they were mostly based on whatever i found when reverse engineering stuff
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (22:20): it's likely the wf2 stuff is based on what i thought would be good, vs html5's stuff which is based on legacy implementations
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (22:21): makes sense since WF2 is a submission format
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (22:21): yeah
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (22:21): however, for consistency, .1 and 1. could be made non-conforming on the non-WF2 side
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (22:21): i'd rather make them conforming on the other side, if they work
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (22:21): but yeah
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (22:21): (especially .1)
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (22:21): I'm not sure if that would help authors, though
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (22:22): I guess they are now as good as they are going to get
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (22:22): and authors just have to deal with the discrepancy with leading/trailing zero omission
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (22:22): what are? authors? :-)
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (22:22): oh, the formats
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (22:22): i'd like them the same if we can
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (22:22): but i'm not sure we can
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (22:25): the wiki list of microsyntaxes keeps growing
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (22:26): 31 already. I'm going to add 2 more
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (22:28): and that's ignoring the inputmode attribute, because magically, it is actually possible to construct with RELAX NG list{}
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (22:31): heh
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (22:33): 69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e: http://lists.w3.org/Archives/Public/ietf-http-wg/2007OctDec/0241.html ‚Äî more mailing list fun
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (22:33): in due course, I should write a by-reference spec for these 33 microsyntaxes
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (22:34): a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554: actually it would make a lot of sense for ABNF to support namespaces
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (22:34): a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554: since it's a programming format

a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (22:34): b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9: if you want oddities in the microsyntaxes in HTML 5, take a look at my emails on public-html (just search the subject for something like detailed spec review of common microsyntaxes)
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (22:35): 69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e: agreed
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (22:35): the biggest problem with ABNF is that it is REALLY freaking hard to write ABNF in a way that defines error handling
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (22:35): that's the main reason i don't use it much
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (22:35): a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554: I don't want oddities. I just think that the RELAX NG datatype library for HTML5 should have a spec

69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (22:35): (i used it for the event-source stuff, and even there, where i was TRYING to define error handling, i still made mistakes, and ended up having to duplicate the work in prose anyway)
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (22:36): precise enough to let someone write an interoperable implementation in another programming language without looking at my code
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (22:36): i've found some sites that use an "adx.js" library
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (22:36): anyone know anything about it?

a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (22:36): 69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e: in reply to the one on the same list yesterday regarding error handling, I got told basically that I could do it in another spec, and they wouldn't do it
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (22:36): a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554: cool, a license to write a replacement http spec from the http group
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (22:36): a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554: sounds like a plan!
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (22:37): RFC2616bisbis
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (22:38): oh maybe this is openads
